TCG Card Shop Simulator is a surprisingly relaxing and satisfying game, especially if you enjoy card collecting or shop-management sims. Opening booster packs, organizing your collection, and selling cards to customers feels great, and the game nails that “card shop owner” vibe. The atmosphere is cozy, and early–mid progression feels rewarding.

However, the game can become repetitive as you get further in. The variety of cards and items is somewhat limited, and some of the economic balance (upgrade prices, profit margins, etc.) can feel grindy. In the end game, the pace slows down a lot — XP becomes harder and harder to earn, which makes leveling feel sluggish and less satisfying. It’s still enjoyable, just noticeably slower.

Overall:
If you enjoy card opening, running a small shop, and playing something chill without stress, this game is worth trying. Just don’t expect huge complexity or fast late-game progression.

Final Rating: In my opinion, the game is a solid 7.5/10.

So I am having to regrettably give this game a negative recommendation, as it is a different game from what it's title would lean many to think it was.  I held back on giving this review as I was hoping some things would change (as many things tend to improve through an EA), but it's direction has completely leaned away from what I was looking for

TCG Card Shop Simulator is a "pack opening" simulator, NOT a simulation of running a card shop.  It's systems are hyper exploitable once you understand what those are, and there is a portion of players on its discord that shout down anyone thinking it should be less so.  If you tried to run your shop with any sort of legitimate business acumen (things like diversifying your products and offerings, or trying to offer deep selections of similar products) the game actively punishes you for it.

Much of this comes from the fact that it's designer is bringing a game concept over from the mobile side of gaming.  This game's predecessor was just a "big number go up" style shop simulator, where you are always just better off offering large amounts of the most expensive products, and ignore everything else.  As one could imagine, if this was always the best thing to do, no one would sell anything other then Lamborghinis anywhere in the world.

So if you just want to collect fake cards and have a game built to where you can easily exploit it and open up thousands of packs of cards, then this game will suit your needs.  If you were hoping for a game that felt like you were running a card shop from the 90s or 00s, this is not going to sufficiently simulate that.  The sad part is, it could have easily moved closer to a center point, with the pack rippers loosing very little, but having to actually manage a card shop was not something some of the early adopters wanted to do.

To me, I feel like this is the PERFECT game if:

A) You're just a stoner who's stoned all day every day, and never leave the house.
B)  You're going through a tough time, you're depressed, and you just want something to keep your mind off whatever is bothering you. 
C) You're the type to have an idle game playing in the background while you work and like to alternate between work and gaming.

If that's the case, you can do no wrong getting this game at a discount. It is absolutely perfect for you if that is the case. 

To anyone else, avoid this game like a plague (unless it is on a deep sale and you're a game hoarder who wants to add more backlog of games you don't play).

Don't get me wrong, I very much enjoyed the game. But halfway through, it really does become a wait and wait type of game as the things you can do become very limited, repetitive, and just plain old boring - and worse, frustrating.

To add to it, i don't really see why this game is considered early access? Like, seriously. Where else can you take this game beyond what is already given? Yes, you can add QOL mechanics and whatnot, but there is little room for a major expansion or a marked improvement in gameplay systems that will make this ten times better than it is.

This feels like the full release, and any updates is just that. Minor improvements and fixes to improve the games QOL. But I doubt it will go beyond what is already here. 

Anyway, I can't recommend this because there is no "neutral" or "mixed" option and I truly believe that the gameplay loop is not for a lot of people once you hit x certain amount of hours. You literally have to be a person with nothing going on his life to enjoy this game as half the game is waiting, and waiting, and waiting.

Now, I might change the rating down the line, but as I looked at my shop at Day 190 with this amount of hours of playtime, I decided that was it. So I had my employees restock the store, placed all my ten graded rare cards in a large wall displays and lower tiers on shelves, and essentially "completed" the store with everything fully stocked and placed accordingly.

By the end of all that, however, I find myself saying:

"Well, this game felt like a waste of time." 

So I promptly fired all my employees and turned off the lights. The store is now a museum with prices jacked up to 2,000% above market price, forever left in its pristine and restocked condition, likely never to be opened again until I reinstall the game.

Maybe one day I'll feel differently, but after all that, I just didn't feel satisfied. I just felt like I wasted my time.

Does it means its a bad game? No. Not at all. This is a good game. But it just doesn't feel satisfying. Maybe that's fine for a lot of you, but I'm pretty damn old now with fortunately time to kill during my time with this game, and I definitely felt like that time wasn't spent well.

As one could imagine, if this was always the best thing to do, no one would sell anything other then Lamborghinis anywhere in the world.

If you were hoping for a game that felt like you were running a card shop from the 90s or 00s, this is not going to sufficiently simulate that.  The sad part is, it could have easily moved closer to a center point, with the pack rippers loosing very little, but having to actually manage a card shop was not something some of the early adopters wanted to do.

So I am having to regrettably give this game a negative recommendation, as it is a different game from what it's title would lean many to think it was.  I held back on giving this review as I was hoping some things would change (as many things tend to improve through an EA), but it's direction has completely leaned away from what I was looking for

TCG Card Shop Simulator is a "pack opening" simulator, NOT a simulation of running a card shop.  It's systems are hyper exploitable once you understand what those are, and there is a portion of players on its discord that shout down anyone thinking it should be less so.  If you tried to run your shop with any sort of legitimate business acumen (things like diversifying your products and offerings, or trying to offer deep selections of similar products) the game actively punishes you for it.

Much of this comes from the fact that it's designer is bringing a game concept over from the mobile side of gaming.  This game's predecessor was just a "big number go up" style shop simulator, where you are always just better off offering large amounts of the most expensive products, and ignore everything else.  As one could imagine, if this was always the best thing to do, no one would sell anything other then Lamborghinis anywhere in the world.

So if you just want to collect fake cards and have a game built to where you can easily exploit it and open up thousands of packs of cards, then this game will suit your needs.  If you were hoping for a game that felt like you were running a card shop from the 90s or 00s, this is not going to sufficiently simulate that.  The sad part is, it could have easily moved closer to a center point, with the pack rippers loosing very little, but having to actually manage a card shop was not something some of the early adopters wanted to do.

The early to mid game is great and addictive however there are 2 major issues with the design of this game and I'll get to both of them now and why I don't believe this game deserves a positive recommendation. 

Leveling:
Everything in the game is unlocked by level 80 and getting there is a slog but doable, shop products are unlocked at a steady pace always keeping you busy. The real issue is what happens after level 80. After level 80 all there is to unlock is warehouse space, space that is valuable so that you can add more card opening machine that open card packs for you while you're doing other tasks. The final warehouse space upgrade is unlocked at level 115. Getting from level 80 to 115 to unlock the final few warehouse space upgrades is INSANE, to the point that it's the most extreme case of game padding I have ever seen. XP required per level needs a huge reduction as the amount of hours  required for a single level up is beyond crazy and it only gets worse requiring more XP the higher your level.

Collecting All Cards:
In order to complete the game you have to collect one of every unique card in the game, this starts off as a fun task that is ongoing since day 1 and is mostly just at the back of your mind while you develop your shop and grow your business. However, you eventually get to the point where everything is unlocked, your shop is fully developed and you focus on the final task in the game - finishing your card collection. You will quickly come to the realisation that the system is horribly designed. Collecting cards needs a huge overhaul or fix. To put into perspective exactly how bad the grind to collect all cards is I'll give you my stats. Card drop rates either need to be dynamic in the sense that the odds increase as the number of missing cards decreases or another method of obtaining cards should be introduced. 

The hard truth is that this game doesn't respect your time and expects you to slave away in a mindless grind to complete it.

I personally found the game extremely boring and repetitive, although it seems I am in the minority in this case. After a couple of hours you have experienced everything the game has to offer. The game feature very few and monotonous actions; restock the shelves, change prices, checkout, open packs. Even these mechanics are mostly eliminated after hiring workers, leaving only opening packs, which is incredibly slow and tedious without modding the game. The cards themselves feature no gameplay benefit or mechanics outside its financial value, making them more so glorified stocks or assets than unique cards. you'll spend most of your time opening packs staring at the corner to see how much they are worth, as its the only thing that even matters. 

Another issue is how bland most of the games merchandise is, as in, items you sell in the game for profit (not irl merch). Most are simply reskins of already existing products in the game, such as different coloured deck boxes, different art on playmats, books with different covers, etc. as such, they only have value as much as they are valued.

From what I understand, a lot of the appeal of the game is opening the packs, which I struggle to see how that can be enjoyable. The cards in the game are essentially knockoff pokemon, with none of the chase cards being very interesting. All the cards have full-art or foil variants, but the thing they lack is any form of alternative art or design to chase. This issue is only more noticeable when unlocking destiny packs, which are identical to the base version, the only difference being the background of the card, and its value. Besides those, the cards are visually identical to the base set, even have the same cards at the same rarity. The only chase cards are "ghost" cards, which happen to be the only alternative art in the game. 

Ultimately, the game is lacking in meaningful progression, which is an issue in "number-go-up" type games. Numbers getting bigger is not engaging if there isn't a purpose or benefit to increasing those numbers, which results in a game of mindless and repetitive progression, for no other incentive than to maybe look at some pokemon card knockoffs. If you are still interested in the game, I recommend purchasing the game on sale, and keep in mind that if you don't like the game within the first hour, you won't like it 50 hours in either, it is the same game, and nothing really changes between these timeframes. I would also recommend modding the game with fast pack opening, ArtExpander and a reskin of the existing cards, as seemingly the modders have more interest in designing a visually appealing game. Retexture mods exist for all of the big three card games (Pokemon TCG, MTG, YGO) and others, such as Dragon ball, hololive, and... gooners apparently (don't turn adult content on in nexus, I'm warning you). Some improvements to the game is having more varied card art, more purpose in collecting or displaying cards outside your own enjoyment, such as improving popularity by displaying cards, or maybe having ranking that compete against other stores? 

Obviously, if you are reading this, don't take my words as gospel, as this my opinion and analysis of the game. Buy the game and try it yourself. If you don't like it, refund it within the first 2 hours, otherwise you might find a game you really enjoy, but alas, as a connoiseur of simulator slop games, I cannot recommend it.

This game is too far removed from reality to have "simulator" in its title. It's an idle game with a trading-card-shop theme. I put a lot of time in looking for a game that just isn't here.

Customers come in who stink, and this upsets your other customers. As a shopkeeper, you're expected to install a machine that detects odorous guests and hoses them down with deodorant. Just like in real life.

When you go to buy products, first you have to buy a license for them. The license gets more expensive as the items go up in level. This means that you'll pay a few hundred bucks for the right to sell Adventure Comic 1, but tens of thousands if you want to stock Adventure Comic 12. 

Once you've bought the license, you can buy the product at wholesale prices. Sometimes, you can buy products in two lot sizes (pack of 32 or pack of 64), they're always exactly the same per-unit price so you don't actually get a bulk discount. Also, if you buy a pack of 8 red deck boxes and a pack of 16 red deck boxes, you're not allowed to store them on the same shelf. Just like in real life.

You can hold up to 8 packs in your hand, but only 1 of anything else. You also can't do anything with anything in your hand except put it back on a shelf. You can only get boxes from emptying out product orders (if you buy a 32-pack of cards, and put them on a shelf, now you have an empty box you can work with). But despite the necessity of having a box to do any kind of inventory rearranging, you can't just produce a box. Fortunately, you can't store empty boxes in your warehouse. Did I say fortunately? I meant "for some insane reason."

I was hoping to glean some insight about how card shops work, how prices are set, how demand is calculated, maybe get a sense of how many boxes of cards a real shop has to sell in a day. Instead, I get a game centered around what feels like a child's guess at how a retail operation works.
